H0.text: Carbon's ability to form crystal structures under certain conditions is a characteristic that makes it essential to living organisms.

H1.text: Carbon can exist as a solid, liquid, or gas, a characteristic that makes it essential to living organisms.

H2.text: Carbon bonding in many ways with itself to form chains is the characteristic that makes carbon essential to living organisms.

H3.text: Carbon exists in radioactive forms is the characteristic of carbon that makes it essential to living organisms.

A4.text: Carbon's ability to form polymers at the temperatures commonly encountered on Earth enables this element to serve as a common element of all known life.

A5.text: Carbon in its solid state exists in several allotropes, including graphite and diamond, which are different crystal structures.

A6.text: One important property of carbon is that it readily forms chains, or networks, that are linked by carbon-carbon (carbon-to-carbon) bonds.
